titleStmt.title:
A Epilouge wrote by Dr 08. Swift,
spoken at a Benefit Night for
the poor Weavers of Dublin.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Who dares affirm this is no pious Age
When Charity begins to mount ye Stage?
When Actors who at best are hardly Savers,
Will give a Night of Benefit to Weavers?
Stay-- Let me see how finely will it sound?
Imprimis. From his Grace a Hundred Pound;
Peers, Clergy, Gentry, all are Benefactors,
And then comes in ye Item of ye Actors,
Item ye Actors freely give a Day,
The Poet had no more yt made ye Play.
But whence this wondrous Charity in Players
They learn it not at Sermons nor at Prayers,
Under ye Rose, since here are none but Friends,
To own ye Truth we have some private Ends.
Since Waiting Women like exacting Iades,
Hold up ye Prices of their old Brocades
We'll dress in Manufactures made at Home,
Equip our Kings & Generals at ye ·(1) Two Places in Dublin, cheifly inhabited by Clothiers. (2). Comb,

We'll rig in ·\Nul; see footnote 1\. Meath-Street ·(3) Cleopatra Mark-Anthony, ye two cheif Characters in ye celebrated Tragedy, of all for Love, or ye World well Lost, alter'd from Shakespear's Anthony Cleopatra, by Mṛ Dryden. Egypts haughty Quen.
And ·(4) The Two cheif Parts of Sophinisba, written by Mr Lee. \Transcriber bungles numbering here, throwing off notes 5-7 as well.\. Anthony shall court her in Ratten;
In Blue Shallon shall ·(5) (6) Alexander ye Great & Roxana one of ye Rival Queen's in ye so called, written by Mṛ Lee aforesaid. (7). Hanibal be \clad·written·above·deleted·drest\
And ·\Nul; see footnote 5.\. Scipio trail an Irish purple Plad.
In Drugget drest of thirteen Pence a Yard
See Philip's Son ·\Nul; see footnote 5.\. amidst his Persian Guard.
And proud Roxana, fir'd with jealous Rage
With fifty Yards of Crape shall sweep ye Stage,
In short our King's & Princess'es: within,
Are all resolv'd ye Project to begin,
And you our Subjects, when you here resort,
Must imitate ye Fashion of ye Court.
O could I see this Audience clad in Stuff,
Tho' Moneys scarce, we should have Trade enough,
But Chints, Brocades, & Lace take all away,
And scarce a Crown is left to see ye Play.
Perhaps you wonder whence this Friendship springs,
Between ye Weavers, & us Play-house Kings,
But Wit & Weaving had ye same Begining,
Pallas first taught us Poetry & Spining,
And next observe how this Alliance fits,
For Weavers now are just as poor as Wits,
Their Brother Quill-men, Workers for ye Stage,
For sorry Stuff can get a Crown a Page,
But Weavers will be kinder to ye Players,
And sell for Twenty Pence a Yard of theirs,
And to your Knowledge there is often less in,
The Poets' Wit than in ye Players' Dressing.
